Award.AwardTitle: CEDAR Workshop 2015 - 2017 and Community Web Pages and Email Services
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the annual summer CEDAR (Coupling, Energetics and Dynamics of Atmospheric Regions) workshop as well as planning activities by the award recipient and the CEDAR Steering Committee. The CEDAR Workshop and associated community services, such as maintenance of a participant database, wiki web pages, and community emails, will be managed by the UCAR Visiting Scientist Program (VSP). The workshop brings together the upper atmospheric research community to share information among students, researchers, and government agencies. The workshop promotes undergraduate and graduate exposure and participation in related sciences. The community web pages and email support also serve to tie the community together.
CEDAR is a broad-based, community-initiated, upper atmospheric research program. The goal is to understand the behavior of atmospheric regions from the middle atmosphere upward through the thermosphere and ionosphere into the exosphere in terms of coupling, energetics, chemistry, and dynamics on regional and global scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project are to organize, hold, and provide student travel funds to the annual summer CEDAR (Coupling, Energetics, and Dynamics of Atmospheric Regions) Workshops.  There has always been a strong emphasis on attracting and retaining students. CEDAR supports undergraduate and graduate student participation, encourages tutorial speakers to consider a braod audience, provide networking opportunities, e.g., at the student-led Sunday Student Workshop, during the Student Poster judging. Individual workshop conveners are encouraged to consider a scientifically broad audience and consider student presenters. Each year approximately thirty individual workshops are organized by CEDAR community members. Each individual workshop has its own wiki page with workshop description, agenda and the option to archive presentations. The CEDAR workshop is the premier workshop for ground-based upper atmosphere researchers, and the best large workshop for student involvement and networking.  Additional services are provided throughout the year to keep the database of names, addresses and emails current, as well as supporting community unity through wiki web pages and CEDAR community emails. 

The CEDAR meetings have been especially helpful in personally and scientifically connecting students and scientists across institutions. Networking is fostered by social events, poster sessions, small individual workshops, student breakfast, and socializing during breaks. Further educational training is available through the tutorials, which are specifically geared toward a broader audience including students, and can be accessed on-line on the CEDAR wiki webpages.

All meetings have provided an opportunity for participants, and especially for students, to interact and network with colleagues. The education benefits of the community created by the CEDAR workshops are invaluable, and are a source of pride at NSF. There is an undergraduate special award in the annual student poster competition each year, as well as the regular first and second place awards. Simply placing in the annual student poster competition is helpful on student resumes. Students organize their own workshop day, usually on Sunday, as well as other student-directed workshops or social activities. The student workshop included a professional development workshop on effective presentation and communication, and the whole CEDAR community learned about digital scholarship and reproducible research in the plenary session.
